event: 10 years old
male
diagnosed with high-risk early T-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia
treated according to LAL SEHOP-PETHEMA 2013 protocol
developed early CNS relapse
treated according to InteReALL HR 2010 with bortezomib protocol
neutropenic for four weeks (20 neutrophils/μL)
prophylaxis with cefepime
prophylaxis with cotrimoxazole
prophylaxis with fluconazole
treated with acyclovir for herpes simplex virus type 1 skin infection
developed intense holocranial headache
cranial computed tomography scan showed hypodense lesion in right temporal lobe
lumbar puncture performed
cefepime replaced by meropenem and vancomycin
developed septic shock signs
transferred to pediatric intensive care unit
inotropic and vasoactive support
antimicrobial spectrum broadened with gentamycin and caspofungin
blood analysis showed progressive increase of C reactive protein
blood analysis showed progressive increase of procalcitonin
hematological analysis showed pancytopenia due to chemotherapy
microbiological blood tests ruled out bacteremia
microbiological blood tests ruled out fungemia
all herpes viruses negative
urine culture negative
stool culture negative
cerebrospinal fluid glucose 63 mg/dL
cerebrospinal fluid proteins 16 mg/dL
cerebrospinal fluid leucocytes 1/µL
B. cereus detected in cerebrospinal fluid
herpes simplex virus 1 and 2 ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
herpes virus 6 ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
cytomegalovirus ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
varicella-zoster virus ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
enterovirus ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
parechovirus ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
toxoplasma ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
Neisseria meningitidis ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
Listeria monocytogenes ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
Streptococcus pneumoniae ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
Cryptococcus ruled out in cerebrospinal fluid
electroencephalogram showed diffuse slowing of brain activity
electroencephalogram showed no epileptiform activity
cranial magnetic resonance performed
cranial magnetic resonance showed two hyperintense lesions in T2 and FLAIR sequences
lesions affecting subcortical region of right temporal lobe
lesions affecting right parietal lobe
parietal lesion presented ring-enhancing after gadolinium administration
lesions showed peripheral diffusion restriction
small hemorrhagic foci dispersed throughout parenchyma
diagnosis of B. cereus abscess
headache resolved
no findings on neurological examination
control magnetic resonance showed decrease in lesion size
vancomycin suspended
acyclovir suspended
meropenem maintained over six weeks
